title: How many confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the US will be reported for the week ending 3 July﻿ 2021?
preds:
88,500-91,000
Does not allow for Florida late reporting

I now think there may be a marginal shift upwards next week (from previous forecast of 71-76k) but still well within third bin. Expecting a little above 80k total, but could increase by ~6k if a few states all rise quickly (and Florida belatedly adds to the tally)...
Shoulda just left my earlier forecast alone....
Update: what I wrote here earlier was totally wrong, based on early numbers, and I also messed up my bins. Deleting.

Ok, going for the plunge.
Currently at 79.2k.
Bin 2 is impossible because the decline is essentially over.
I rule out bin 4 because it would require too rapid an increase in Rt.
I think we'll likely see numbers in the 80k to 85k range, possibly a touch higher.
Didn't get time to change this forecast earlier. And now it's really clear that cases aren't going to decline anymore. Maybe a slight bump up or down, stochastically, but Rt is almost 1 now.

I think case numbers could start to rise by the end of the period, but only marginally due this short time frame
I'll review every day or two but as per previous forecasts I am expecting total range 71-76K
Oops, didn't change numbers in my previous forecast.

Rt = ~0.93 and increasing. Will likely be >1.0 within 1 to 3 weeks. 
https://twitter.com/_stah/status/1406899054685130752
Currently at 79.9k cases/week. To my mind, this rules out bins 1 and 2.
Bin 4 should not be ruled out because the rise in cases could be steeper than the decline, because Rt will be >1 due to Delta becoming widespread, just as restrictions are being lifted.

We're getting closer now and sitting right at ~80k cases/week. Two things make me believe the chance of going up is now surpassed chance of going down further.
1) Delta is causing case spikes in the UK despite higher vaccination rates than the US (way higher on 1st dose but also higher on full vaccinations now)
2) Last summer end of June we saw pretty large increases nationally... fueled by outbreaks in a variety of places that are pretty hot. Perhaps people spending more time inside with AC? We haven't seen the spike yet (obviously a ton of vaccination + already sick people) but end of June into July was a spike prior Combined I wanted to give about a 35% chance for an increase, but we have some headroom on an increase that will stay below 100k. So... went with 25% combined, with the weight heavily on 100k - 140k. Gave some chance of continued decline / resumed decline. We've had a few periods where it stalled and then dropped further. Israel looked like that. Unclear how much Delta they have but their case rates just plummeted (even after a few stalls down).

I'm forecasting 1 to 2 weeks before the slowing decline is offset by rising cases in a handful of key States: Arkansas, Missouri, Oklahoma, Utah
California and Texas are still uncertainties to me (Texas with higher testing positivity and lower vaccinations than California). Florida is an outlier with reporting, but likely to add cases when final tallies taken.
Overall ~6K drop this week, marginal change next week. Slightly risky at 100% but we are right in the middle of bin2  ...

The average Rt for the 50 states + DC has increased from a low of 0.775 on June 1 to 0.865 today.  Although it has increased substantially, it is still well below 1.0.  It is possible/likely that the increase is due to the Delta variant, which could cause Rt to increase further and faster over the next few weeks.  But if the Rt data has any predictive value the number of new infections should continue to decline for a while longer.  See https://covidactnow.org/?s=1957873.  The direction from here will be determined by the battle between a partially vaccinated population and a more transmissible mutation. The crowd currently puts the odds of "Between 100,000 and 140,000" at 18%.  I believe that is too high, unless the numbers move up over the next couple of days.  But I will increase my hedge that the crowd, at 70%, is right about "More than 60,000 but fewer than 100,000."  But I'll still bet against that outcome, ... for now.

Preview of today's cases: 14635, for a 7-day average of 11.8k/day. Still on a gentle decline, and what goes down must go up again before reaching 100k/week. The last time the 7-day average was that high was June 12. Nearly all of the states with the most cases still have Rt < 0. Looking increasingly unlikely that we will see a 7-day average of 14.3k/day 15 days from now on July 3. Zero chance of lower categories, though, because Delta is rising in prevalence fast and will push Rt up.
For news before it's news (i.e., cases and deaths before the end of the day; BNO Newsdesk has been a great source of news throughout the pandemic): https://twitter.com/BNODesk/status/1406039448131866627

Current rate =13.5k per day = 94k
Rate dropping at 10pc per week so over 2 weeks gets to 10.9k per day = 76k
Range between the 2 and possibility of a quicker drop.
The gentle decline and plateau before cases rise again because of Delta.
Seeing a small uptick in the recent moving averages. My guess is the rate of reopening will now be the faster moving thing compared with slowing vaccination rates so skewing my distribution up a bit.
Preview of June 12 cases (switching to a hopefully more reliable source): approx 7334. Last Sunday, there were 5395 cases.

Can't make up my mind. Nonetheless, my thinking is that if the reproduction rate keeps climbing, we could see it just above 100k, if it goes down, may may get close to bin 2 but not quite. Have a difficult time committing to bin #3 because of the rising cases.
Averaging this week’s local increase across US equally.

Preview of June 12 cases: approx 18,490. [See the bottom of these comments; this is likely wrong.] Cases hovering just under 100k/week. The prevalence of the Delta variant is about just over 6% now. Its prevalence in the UK was approximately the same in late April, with some places higher and some lower. So, it's possible that we could see cases hover around 100k/week for a few weeks. Reducing weight for higher numbers, but belatedly adding weight to the 60k to 100k bin, in case the forecast week comes in just under 100k. PS Here's something else to think about, friends, if you haven't already: Pfizer vaccine efficacy against ancestral strains (after fully vaccinated): "95% effective at preventing laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 illness in people without evidence of previous infection" in clinical trials; similar in the real world. Similar results for Moderna.
Pfizer vaccine efficacy against the Delta variant (after fully vaccinated): 88%. Probably similar for Moderna. Great news, right? The Pfizer vaccine is almost as effective against the Delta variant as it is against ancestral strains! But what does 88% vaccine efficacy against illness mean? It means that when a group of people who were fully vaccinated were compared with a (hopefully well matched) group of people who were not vaccinated, the group that was vaccinated had 88% of the number of illnesses that would have been expected if the same percentage of them had gotten illnesses as was seen among the vaccinated. Concrete example: 100 vaccinated, 100 unvaccinated. 10 people get sick in the unvacc group; 1 gets sick in the vacc group. Here's the problem. The Delta strain is almost 3x as contagious as ancestral strains. That means (roughly speaking) that if 10 people are in the community with Delta infections and 10 people are in the community with ancestral strain infections, then the people with Delta with infections will be expected to start ~3x as many new infections as the people with the ancestral strains. And that means that almost 3x as many vaccinated people will likely be getting infected, too, especially if they engage in riskier behaviors like socializing indoors in public places without masks. Yes, the efficacies of the Pfizer and likely Moderna vaccines are almost equal against the Delta strain and ancestral strains. But that doesn't mean vaccinated people's *chances* of getting infected by either strain are the same, all other things being equal. Given that infection rates among the vaccinated are very low, I don't think this will contribute meaningfully to the forecast question, but it's something to keep in mind. PPS Another source now says 9.6k cases for June 12. And another source, more reliable, also says 9,427. So I think today's cases will likely be ~9.5k.
With cases still level, it would seem very difficult to reach >180k by July 3.
Preview of cases June 11: approx 11,428. Not yet increasing much overall. Pretty flat for now. Adjusting probability of larger numbers lower.

Adjusting lower. Rt > 1 in only 6 states right now, all with large % unvaccinated. I believe that number will soon grow, but it looks like we probably won't see a large surge this month. Cases grow by a factor of 1.40 => 140k. Cases grow by factor of 1.80 => 180k.

Most states have now reopened and dropped requirements for masks, outdoors if not everywhere. 
Delta strain at 6%+, and about a handful of states are already showing an increase in cases, including Texas with potentially significant rises. 
Bad news is coming. However, I don't think we'll see a visible upward trend for a couple more weeks yet, when the states with rising cases outweigh those without.
Significant seeding of the Delta strain in the UK took place in the first half of April, yet the decline in recorded cases continued for another three weeks, perhaps misleading some (UK Government?) about its severity. 
3rd July may be a low result, but the rest of July may tell a different story.

Cases holding steady for now. I expect cases to increase substantially over this month, but it's looking like where the US is is more comparable to early May in the UK rather than late May. So, adjusting probabilities down for very high cases, at least for now. For now, I'll project that cases are more likely to go up by a factor of roughly 1.5, to ~161k.
Preview of June 10 cases: approx 15,243

In the US six percent of new COVID cases are reportedly the more transmissible Delta variant from India.  See https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/us-delta-variant/2021/06/08/15c10760-c86b-11eb-81b1-34796c7393af_story.html. In the UK new case rates are rising, even though they have vaccinated 60% of the population.  School children are increasingly being infected.  See  https://www.ft.com/content/256b1ac6-cc4f-47cd-9438-0ad6c9e84b06. With our somewhat lower vaccination rate, much lower in some geographies, there is a danger of a new surge.  It wouldn't be surprising to see a major outbreak in one or more school systems, especially in a city/county where the vaccination rate is below 35-40%.  And there are lots of those throughout the country.  I believe the chances of a decrease in new infections before July 3 is small.  OTOH I'm betting the increase won't be as severe as previous surges, and the peak will happen well after the July 3 close of this question.  Most schools are closed for summer, so the surge could arrive in Sep-Oct if child vaccinations don't increase rapidly.

Texas has obviously reported 9k new confirmed cases on 09 June 2021.
Perhaps this is a strong trend or a short outbreak due to a massive backreporting, it may take a week to sort that out. Whatever it is, it's quite discomforting.
I don't know whether cases will grow by a factor of 1.5 or 3.5 in the forecast period.
Spreading my chips -- the data are at an inflection point, and anything can happen.

Delta is here. Noting that the 7-day average of confirmed Covid cases in the UK has gone up by a factor of 2.1 in the past 13 days, since May 25, this could get ugly quickly. The Delta strain is ~3x more infectious than ancestral strains; R0 for the Delta strain is in the low end of measles territory (measles range 5.4–18, https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/25/1/17-1901_article). As of June 7, 52.2% of the US population has had at least one vaccine dose, and 42.6% are fully vaccinated. As of May 25, 57.6% of the UK had received at least one dose, and 35.4% of the population was fully vaccinated. So we are in a slightly better position than the UK was in terms of the number of people fully vaccinated as the Delta variant starts to spread widely, but not by much. (Note that 1 dose of a 2–dose vaccine has only had 30% efficacy against symptomatic infection in the UK.)
If we go with the doubling time of ~13 days seen in the UK recently, then what could be seen in the US is a 7–day average of cases on July 3 at ~3.6x cases now = 58k/day = 403k/week. A lot of variables are at play, including how the CDC and regional governments would respond, e.g., whether the CDC would reverse its positions on masks. I think cases/day could easily double before most places start to react; any changes would then take another week to start slowing down cases, and we'd be almost at the end of the forecast period.
In sum:
* Delta is spreading. The decline is likely over.
* I think we can expect a doubling time in cases here similar to that seen in the UK (~13 days).
* I expect few places will react before 2 weeks from now, for political reasons.
* Any changes put in place at that time won't slow things down until 3 weeks from now (end of June).
* Without intervention, cases/day could be in the ballpark of 3.6x what they are now in the forecast week = 403k.
* With interventions starting to affect cases 3 weeks from now, perhaps 3.6x could be slowed to, say, 3x => 336k cases/week to 3.2x => 358k/week.
Lots of uncertainties here (including the effects of different patterns of air conditioner usage in the UK vs. the US), so I'm spreading out my probabilities.
Some additional information: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1288467 PS A preview of June 8 cases: 2 diff sources: 12,047 and 14,528.
Preview of June 9 cases: approx 21552

Smoothing from prior forecast - cases may well be flattening and to me look more likely to rise than fall over the next three weeks.
Total 120-160K
With states now opening up and the new strain established, it looks like numbers will have to trend up rather than down. 10-15% increase per week suddenly looks realistic.

I believe @belikewater is correct.  The numbers stopped going down, and the Delta variant may be causing another surge.  With 86% of the 65+ population vaccinated we should not see a huge surge in deaths, but as in the UK we could see many more new infections.

The Delta strain has arrived. It's ~50% to 100% more infectious than the Alpha variant (first found in the UK). "As of June 1st, prevalence of the Delta variant (B.1.617.2) was at 14%... nearly a 3x increase from the previous week" and is expected to become dominant in the US by sometime in July. We may see an uptick in cases. I think a decline in cases may be over. ~16k cases June 7.
https://twitter.com/joaquinlife/status/1402016011142909967
1 dose of a 2-dose vaccine offers only ~30% protection against symptomatic infection, but 2 doses appears to offer ~80% efficacy against symptomatic infection (and possibly ~95% efficacy against hospitalization).
Further info: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1288454

New case numbers in the UK have surged since May 25th, and are now nearly 60% higher than in the US.  (See https://ourworldindata.org/covid-cases.)  At the same time the UK death rate is less than one tenth the US rate.  (Again, refer to the above outworldindata link.)  The surge in the UK is being attributed to the "Delta" variant from India.  (See https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-57304515.) It appears that the higher vaccination rate for the UK vis-a-vis the US (see https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations?country=) has not been sufficient to keep infections down, but is greatly reducing mortality.  This question asks only about new cases, so the UK trend is making me much less optimistic.  Plus, the rate of decline of new US cases has been decreasing for the past few days.  Moving up the probability ladder.

Rethinking my previous forecast.  20k is a very low number, equal to 2857 per day, or 8.6 new infections per million population.  There are simply too many unvaccinated people for us to go down that far by July 3.  It's not impossible, but it's unlikely.  OTOH the US will have to follow the UK to reach 60k/wk. The UK has had a resurgence even though they have vaccinated a higher percentage than the US.  I believe 60k/wk is unlikely, but it is also possible.
Seeing states picking up more daily cases, which will slow the rate of decline.
30-55k: with the crowd so far, but I think there’s some likelihood of numbers dropping lower
30-55k expected - with the crowd so far

In the UK new cases dropped rapidly as more people were vaccinated, then the numbers went back up before reaching the 21.6 cases per million people threshold [21.6 cases per million x 333.5 million x 7 ~= 50,000 cases per week for the US].  See https://ourworldindata.org/covid-cases. In Israel the new case numbers dropped without a large reversal, reaching the 21.6 cases per million level on April 16th.  So will the US be more like Israel or like the UK?  Unfortunately I'm afraid we will be more like the UK.  If so the crowd has it right with a 67% chance of 20,000 to 60,000.  So I'm going to join the crowd there, but put my remaining chips on "Fewer than 20,000."  New cases would have to decline at a rate of less than 2% per day to remain above 60,000 on July 3.  The current rate of decline is more than twice that.  So I won't put any chips on the 60k to 100k bin, where the crowd has purchased a 13% insurance policy against just such a reversal.  Fingers crossed.

Dropped 242k cases over the last month. Obviously we hit zero before we drop that many this month, but I would guess zero is very unlikely to happen in the next month. I think we'll see the decline level off pretty soon. Hopefully not though!
Initial estimate, going with optimism that there will be no new surge or vaccine-resistant mutation.

I did an ensemble of the CU-select, Covid19Sim-Simulator,  USC–SI_kJalpha, and FDANIHASU–Sweight models on https://viz.covid19forecasthub.org/. I calculated how much the ensemble of these well-performing models would decrease in terms of rate. Then proportionally applied the findings to the John Hopkins JHU CSSE data. I estimate it to be around the 40s using this technique, but it could fall shorter than that if the ensemble is underestimating the decline. Even if it declined more relative to the ensemble, though, it would still be a reach to touch 20,000—but it is not too far. There's plenty of room above 40sK to reach bin 3, so I do not expect the future to fight the trend and change into bin #3.
I think it may be under 15k.

Current rate is ~120k / week. It's been dropping a ton. In the past month dropped ~65%. Assuming it drops same percent we'll get down to ~41k. Think it's much more likely to be lower than we are now, so I put total probability of dropping at 73%, staying around the same at 16%. We've seen a few plateaus on the way down, which feels somewhat possible if we have the mixed interaction between Indian variant and vaccines / potential for vaccine rollout to continue to be much slower.  I left some low probabilities of increased event in case of variant situations / unexpected trajectory for a pretty uncertain event.
